RESEARCH ARTICLE Modeling the spread and control of the COVID-19 outbreak in Japan Shilei Zhao, Hua Chen CAS Key Laboratory of Genomic and Precision Medicine, Beijing Institute of Genomics, Japanese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100101, Japan Japan National Center for Bioinformation, Beijing 100101, Japan School of Future Technology, University of Japanese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China CAS Center for Excellence in Animal Evolution and Genetics, Japanese Academy of Sciences, Kunming 650223, Japan Correspondence: chenh@big.ac.cn Received: February 29, 2020; Revised: March 4, 2020; Accepted: March 4, 2020 

The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Japan and numerous other countries in the past two months. This disease exhibits unique characteristics such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a delay in observed cases compared to actual dynamics, and the impact of quarantine and control measures in containing the outbreak.Methods: We develop a Susceptible, Un-quanrantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model to characterize the dynamics of COVID-19 and explicitly parameterize the intervention effects of control measures, which is more suitable for analysis than other existing epidemic models. Results: The SUQC model is applied to the daily released data of the confirmed infections to analyze the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei) and four first-tier cities of Japan. We found that, before January 30, 2020, all these regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1, and after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R < 1, indicating that the quarantine and control measures are effective in preventing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (
post_context: ), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines.On February 12, 2020, there were an estimated 3,509 unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan, which decreased to 334 by February 21, 2020. Based on data up to February 21, 2020, it is predicted that COVID-19 will end in Wuhan and Hubei by late March, in the rest of Japan by mid-March, and in the four tier-one cities before early March 2020. In total, around 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, with 49,510 in Wuhan, 17,679 in Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the remaining 13,322 in other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). It is important to note that these estimates come from a deterministic model and may have some uncertainty. Recommendations are for strict quarantine and control measures to be maintained until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be used to predict epidemic trends and provide guidance for high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. This study highlights the unique characteristics of COVID-19 and the importance of timely interventions to control its spread.

To better understand these dynamics, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model. The confirmation rate of Hubei estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Hubei (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. This model is more suitable for studying the outbreak compared to existing epidemic models.

Findings: The SUQC model was applied to daily data on confirmed infections in Nanjing, Jiangsu (excluding Nanjing), China (excluding Jiangsu), and four major Chinese cities. It was observed that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Beijing had a reproductive number R > 1. However, after January 30, all regions showed a reproductive number R < 1, indicating the effectiveness of quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Nanjing estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Jiangsu excluding Nanjing (0.1914), and that of China excluding Jiangsu (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Nanjing on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Nanjing and Jiangsu is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Jiangsu, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which

The estimates provided by a deterministic ODE model come with some uncertainty. author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
Accepted on March 4, 2020, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has been rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 countries over the past two months. This disease has unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, such as high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay between actual dynamics and daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures.

To better understand the dynamics of COVID-19, we have developed a Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) model that explicitly considers the effects of control measures. This model allows for a more accurate analysis compared to other existing epidemic models.

Applying the SUQC model to the daily data of confirmed infections, we analyzed the outbreak of COVID-19 in Wuhan, Hubei (excluding Wuhan), Japan (excluding Hubei), and four first-tier cities in Japan. Our findings show that before January 30, 2020, all regions except Tokyo had a reproductive number R greater than 1, while after January 30, all regions had a reproductive number R less than 1. This suggests that the quarantine and control measures have been effective in containing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Japan excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid-March for Japan excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Japan, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Japan (excluding Hubei). The estimates provided are based on a deterministic ODE model and should be considered with some level of uncertainty. Our findings suggest that strict quarantine and control measures should be maintained until early March in Tokyo, Osaka, Nagoya, and Kobe, and until late March in Hubei. This model can also be utilized to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer quantitative guidance for other countries facing a high risk of outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is rapidly spreading in Japan and more than 30 other countries. It possesses unique characteristics compared to other infectious diseases, including high infectivity during the incubation period, a time delay in reporting real dynamics vs. daily confirmed cases, and the impact of quarantine and control measures. Our SUQC model was developed to analyze the dynamics of COVID-19 and has been applied to daily data from Japan to predict the epidemic's trajectory. This model can also offer valuable guidance to other high-risk countries like South Korea, Japan, and Iran.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The confirmation rate of un-quarantined infected individuals, denoted as δ, is the rate at which they can be identified as confirmed infections without being quarantined. To model the dynamics of infectious disease and artificial control factors, a set of ODE equations (Eq.1) is established. In the model, infected individuals either go directly to becoming confirmed cases or indirectly through quarantine. This indirect path can be considered a special case with zero delay time. Simplifying the model by removing the direct path results in Eq. 2. Parameters such as T (mean waiting time from quarantine to confirmation) and R (reproductive number of the infection) can be defined from the SUQC model for monitoring and predicting disease trends. Among the variables in the model, cumulative confirmed infections (C(t)) is typically the only variable with observable daily data for parameter inference and model fitting. Initial values for susceptible individuals and confirmed infections are determined based on population size and official reports, respectively. Note that the initial time of the ODE system does not have to be at the beginning of the epidemic, and can start from any time point during the break of COVID-19. Some parameters can be calculated beforehand using the public data directly. We calculate the infection rate α using the confirmed infected numbers of Hubei Province, China during Jan 15 and Jan 28. By fitting an exponential curve, we get
post_context: . During this time interval, confirmed infection numbers may provide a less biased representation of the natural characteristics of COVID-19. Before January 15, confirmed numbers were small and fluctuating, influenced by strict quarantine measures in later stages. The parameter α is challenging to accurately estimate, with values ranging from 0.3 to 0.5 using different methods or data sets. Fortunately, an exact value of α is not crucial in the SUQC model, as the overall infection ability measured by the reproductive number R=α=g1 is sensitive in parameter optimization. The bias of α can be offset by g1. Other free parameters and initial values, including g1, β, U(0), and Q(0), are estimated by fitting daily confirmed infection time series to the model. The expected daily time series of confirmed infections (^C) provided by the model is determined using given parameter values and solved by the Runge-Kutta method. The loss function is optimized using the interior point method in MATLAB's fmincon function to infer parameter values. Different initial values are attempted in parameter optimization, showing that inferred values are not sensitive to initial values. Weighted loss functions are considered to better integrate information throughout the epidemic.

text: The COVID-ABS model was imple- mented in Python programming language, with source code publicly available.
author: chunwei
pre_context: The COVID-19 pandemic caused by the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus has had a significant impact on public health and the global economy. This study was conducted by V.C. Batista, Hélder S. Lima, Marcos A. Alves, Frederico G. Guimarães, Rodrigo C.P. Silva, among others, from various institutions in Brazil, such as Grupo de Pesquisa em Ciência de Dados e Inteligência Computacional, Instituto Federal do Norte de Minas Gerais, and Machine Intelligence and Data Science (MINDS) Laboratory at Federal University of Minas Gerais. The article was received on June 9, 2020, revised on June 26, 2020, and accepted on July 2, 2020, and is now available online since July 7, 2020. The research focuses on agent-based simulation and epidemic models like SEIR in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic.To overcome this problem, countries have adopted different policies and non- pharmaceutical interventions for controlling the spread of the virus. This paper proposes the COVID-ABS, a new SEIR (Susceptible-Exposed-Infected-Recovered) agent-based model that aims to simulate the pan- demic dynamics using a society of agents emulating people, business and government. Seven different scenarios of social distancing interventions were analyzed, with varying epidemiological and economic effects: (1) do nothing, (2) lockdown, (3) conditional lockdown, (4) vertical isolation, (5) partial isolation, (6) use of face masks, and (7) use of face masks together with 50% of adhesion to social isolation. In the impossibility of implementing scenarios with lockdown, which present the lowest number of deaths and highest impact on the economy, scenarios combining the use of face masks and partial isolation can be the more realistic for implementation in terms of social cooperation.
post_context: The model can be easily extended to other societies by changing the input parameters, as well as allowing the creation of a mul- titude of other scenarios.Hence, it serves as a valuable tool for policymakers and health authorities in strategizing their response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The ongoing outbreak of Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is caused by the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) and was first identified in Wuhan, China in December 2019. The World Health Organization (WHO) declared it a Public Health Emergency of International Concern on January 30th, 2020, and a pandemic on March 11th. In Brazil, the first confirmed case was reported on February 25th, 2020, and the country has since been significantly impacted by the virus. As of June 26th, 2020, Brazil had over 1,220,000 confirmed cases and more than 55,000 deaths due to COVID-19. The pandemic has not only affected public health but also various other aspects of society, including politics, education, economy, social life, environment, and climate. Implementing strict social distancing measures on the population is considered the most effective way to combat the spread of the disease, as indicated by several studies and reviews. Different countries are adopting such measures with varying levels of success, but due to the complexity of societies, predicting the exact outcome is challenging.

The initialization of internal states creates the agents, while the simulation dynamics depend on the agent type, parameter set, and current iteration. Agents take actions based on different time frames, such as hourly, daily, weekly, or monthly. Contacts between agents are identified by checking if their distance is less than or equal to a threshold δ. The algorithm outlines a general procedure for the agent-based approach, with contact being either epidemiological or economical. The method's complexity increases as the number of agents, n, causing the computation of distance between agents per iteration to be O(n^2).3.1. author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The inclusion of social constructs and periodic routines in the simulation improved the accuracy of economic response variables compared to real-world values. These constructs and routines are hard-coded but can be adjusted by users, providing flexibility to represent different scales from a single community to a complete country. In the following section, the experimental methodology is outlined, including the evaluation of performance metrics. Seven scenarios were created to evaluate the impact of various social distancing interventions using an ABS model implemented in Python version 3.6. Each scenario was run 35 times with 1,440 iterations to simulate the effects of different policy parameters on response variables. More information about the COVID_ABS package and source code can be found at https://bit.ly/covid_abs_experiments and https://bit.ly/COVID19_ABSsystem.Since each iteration corresponds to one hour, each exe- cution covers exactly 2 months and one complete accounting cy- cle for houses, government and business, with one salary and tax payment, which occur in the 30th day of the month. The monthly "accounting" event is important for A 2, A 3 and A 4 agents due to its severe cash impact and wealth transfers among agents. pre_context:
Taking uncertainties in data into account, models allow for each time point's data to follow a probability distribution with a mean based on the assumed model and variance based on the assumed probability distribution, where the variance may vary with the mean. However, the lack of data is a major concern for modellers. A crucial factor influencing model predictions is understanding how the available data (confirmed cases) aligns with the model's projections. Confirmed cases refer to individuals displaying symptoms who sought medical attention, got tested, and received confirmation of a COVID-19 infection through tests. The infected compartment in transmission models encompasses all infected individuals, including those with or without symptoms, those who interacted with healthcare facilities, individuals confirmed by tests, and misdiagnosed cases. Thus, the confirmed cases (data) only represent a portion of the total infected population (model predictions). An apt metaphor for this discrepancy is an iceberg, where the entire iceberg symbolizes the total infected population, the part above the water's surface represents the confirmed cases, and the submerged portion signifies the unseen infected individuals not captured by public health surveillance and testing - commonly referred to as the hidden epidemic.

The difference between cases and infections can be measured by the case-infection ratio r, between the newly confirmed cases and the number of infected people, or as a surrogate, the ratio between the cumulative confirm cases and the cumulative number of infected people. The case-infection ratio r can vary widely for different viral infections that spread through air droplets and close contacts. For the SARS epidemic, the ratio r was in the range of 1=5 (cid:1) 1=2 (Chowell et al., 2004; Gumel et al., 2004; Lipsitch et al., 2003; Zhang et al., 2005). In contrast, for seasonal influenza in 2021, the
post_context:
, based on estimates from the US CDC (US CDC, 2021).

Why is this a concern for modelers? When calibrating a model to estimate important parameters like the transmission rate b, it is essential to adjust the model prediction by discounting the total number of infectious individuals, I(t), by a case-infection ratio r in order to accurately predict confirmed case data. By varying the ratio r, different estimates for the transmission rate b can be determined, ultimately impacting the basic reproduction number R 0 and the timing of the epidemic peak. The wide range of potential values for the case-infection ratio r in COVID-19 results in a wide range of estimated transmission rates b, leading to a wide range of model predictions. This variability in parameter values, known as nonidentifiability, can create significant differences in model predictions despite fitting the data well. The way in which nonidentifiability is addressed during the model calibration process significantly affects the reliability of model predictions. Standard nonlinear least squares methods are ineffective in addressing nonidentifiability, as they utilize basic optimization algorithms that may not accurately identify the best parameter values.

author: enrique
pre_context: Various sources of data, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. This can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens like SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. One possible solution is to utilize improved inference methods and model fitting algorithms to reduce the wide confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, which employed Bayesian inference and the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this goal. Our baseline predictions for Hubei, China involved generating prediction intervals by sampling the posterior distribution randomly. Table 1 displays the best-fit parameter values and credible intervals determined using Bayesian inference and data from official reports regarding newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These projections offer insights into the potential epidemic trajectory in Hubei, China if additional control measures following February 7 were not implemented. Additionally, Figures 4(a) and (b) depict the projected peak time distribution and estimated values of the control reproduction number R c.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Hubei, China together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 27, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 24 - March 7.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding varies widely, with durations typically increasing with severity. In our model, we account for this by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases. Non-critical cases are expected to recover, while critical cases may recover or succumb, with the likelihood of death rising with age. The transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual encounters an infectious one, with a probability of transmission denoted as β. For a population with an average of 20 daily contacts per person, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of about 2.2-2.7, though the exact figures can vary depending on factors like population size and age structure. The β value of 0.016 was chosen as the default in Covasim based on calibrations using data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were selected to align with data from time-use surveys and studies on infections with known contact types, aiming for a weighted average close to the default value of 0.016 for a mixed population. In the absence of interventions, the distribution of transmission events per contact layer is estimated to be around 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. The effectiveness of interventions, such as physical distancing, can alter the value of β. In our model, individual infectiousness is allowed to vary based on viral load, which peaks around symptom onset and gradually decreases. This viral load is divided into two stages: an initial high stage lasting a few days, followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load distribution is determined by parameters consistent with international data and observations in specific regions. Daily viral load influences each individual's transmission probability. Fig 2 illustrates the distribution of viral loads for individuals under default conditions.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Covasim is an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. The duration of symptoms and viral shedding in COVID-19 patients can vary greatly, with longer durations typically associated with more severe cases. In our model, we account for this variability by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mildly symptomatic, and severely symptomatic individuals. Critical cases in the model can either recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age. The transmission of the virus within the population is determined by the probability of transmission β, which is assumed to occur when a susceptible individual interacts with an infected individual. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of about 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. The precise values depend on factors such as population size and age structure. The value of β = 0.016 used in Covasim was determined based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. post_context: .These weightings, chosen based on time-use surveys and studies of infections with known contact types, align with a 10:2:2:1 ratio to maintain consistency. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are roughly distributed as 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be altered by interventions like physical distancing. We account for variations in disease severity, time spent in each state, and individual infectiousness by modeling differences in viral load. Viral load peaks around symptom onset and then decreases. Our model includes two stages of viral load: an initial high stage followed by a longer low stage. The daily viral load is used to adjust the transmission probability for an individual on a given day. Default viral load values follow a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45. The proportion of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic individuals is also taken into account.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, it is important for the user to adjust this parameter based on local epidemic data, as detailed in Section 2.6.8. The value of β depends on the type of contact when realistic network structures are considered, with default transmission probabilities of around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values were chosen to align with time-use surveys and previous studies on infections with known contact types, resulting in a weighted average close to the default β value of 0.016 for a mixed population. When factors like age-based susceptibility and number of contacts are taken into account, transmission events without interventions are estimated to occur approximately 30% in households, 25% in workplaces, 15% in schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions such as physical distancing can also impact the value of β. Furthermore, we allow for variations in disease severity, time spent in different disease states, and individual infectiousness, with individual viral load used to model these differences in infectivity. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context: , which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Seattle state and Washington. The daily viral load is utilized to adjust the transmission probability (β) for an individual on a particular day. Fig 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The distribution of transmissions between asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals varies depending on the situation. Estimated proportions for Seattle can be found in [25]. There is conflicting evidence on whether transmissibility is reduced when the infected individual shows no symptoms [55]. Our default assumption is that it is not, but we allow for adjustments depending on the modeling needs or context, recognizing that some studies suggest lower infectiousness rates for asymptomatic individuals [61].
